title: My Webpage
text:
A little about me is that, I am a data enthusiast who loves to explore and visualize data. I have a background in statistics and computer science, and I enjoy learning new tools and techniques for data analysis.





Happiness is the best way to describe me. I always try to find joy in the little things in life and spread positivity to those around me..

title: About
text:
About this site

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
Course: Introduction to Statistics
Year: 2025 (The year of data exploration) Tools: R and ggplot2

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
Course: Introduction to Statistics
Year: 2025 (The year of data exploration) Tools: R and ggplot2

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
The Story
For my statistics class final project, I wanted to analyze how study time affects exam scores. I collected data from 30 classmates who agreed to share their study hours and final exam scores. I was curious: does more studying always mean better grades?

title: Data Visualization Project
text: The Visualization

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
What’s Visualized

X-axis: Study hours per week (numerical values: 5 to 30 hours)
Y-axis: Exam scores (numerical values: 50 to 100 points)
Blue dots: Each represents one student’s study hours and exam score
Red line: Trend line showing the general relationship

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
Key Findings

Positive correlation: Generally, more study hours = higher exam scores
Diminishing returns: After about 20 hours, extra studying doesn’t guarantee much improvement
Variation: Some students scored well with moderate studying, others studied a lot but didn’t score as high

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
Why I Chose This Visualization
I used a scatter plot with trend line because:

Simple and clear: Easy for anyone to understand
Shows individual data points: You can see each student’s situation
Shows overall trend: The line makes the pattern obvious
Two numeric variables: Perfect for showing relationship between study hours and scores

title: Data Visualization Project
text:
What I Learned
This project taught me that data visualization helps reveal patterns that aren’t obvious from just by simply looking at numbers. The scatter plot clearly showed that while studying helps, it’s not the only factor affecting grades.

This was my first real data visualization project and sparked my interest in data science.
← Back to Home

title: About
text:
My Final Year Project
My final year project prior to entering SIT is a web application that visualizes the sentiment analysis of Twitter data related to COVID-19. The application allows users to explore the sentiments expressed in tweets about COVID-19 over time and across different regions. The project involved data collection, preprocessing, sentiment analysis using natural language processing techniques, and creating interactive visualizations using R Shiny.

title: Hobbies: Volunteering
text:
In my free time, I find joy and purpose in volunteering. It started as a way to give back to my community, but it has become a meaningful part of my life that teaches me about empathy, teamwork, and gratitude.




Every last weekend of the month from 9 AM to 12 PM, I help at Hougang SunLove Centre where I: - Sort and pack food donations - Assist with distribution to families in need - Help organize inventory



I volunteered as a phonics tutor for kindergarten students every Saturday morning under Youth Corps: - Prepare simple, engaging phonic activities in the Khan Academy Kids app - See students gain confidence in their abilities - Build rapport with kids from diverse backgrounds



Occasionally, I help with: - Charity runs and fundraising events - Holiday donation drives - Community festivals
















If you’re interested in volunteering:

Start small - Even 2 hours a month makes a difference
Choose what you enjoy - You’ll stick with it longer
Check local websites for volunteer opportunities
Bring a friend - It’s more fun together!





Gratitude: Appreciating what I have
Patience: Things take time to improve
Community: We’re all connected
Leadership: Taking initiative in group activities
Balance: Making time for both studies and service


“The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.” - Mahatma Gandhi
Volunteering has taught me that small actions, when multiplied by many people, can transform the world.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
For this assessment, I primarily used DeepSeek as my main GenAI assistant. I chose this tool because:

Accessibility: It’s free and available through web browsers
Code Support: Excellent at generating and debugging R, Quarto, and GitHub code
Contextual Understanding: Can maintain context across long conversations about the project
Educational Approach: Explains concepts rather than just giving answers






# Example: Before GenAI, I didn't know how to:
# - Link R code with HTML output

# GenAI provided step-by-step instructions for:
# - Creating the project structure
# - Setting up _quarto.yml configuration



When I encountered errors like: - GitHub Pages showing “Upgrade” instead of settings - R code chunks not rendering properly
GenAI helped me: - Diagnose the root cause (private repository issue, missing packages) - Provide specific fix commands - Explain why the error occurred so I could learn from it



For the Data Visualization page, GenAI helped me: - Choose appropriate graph types (scatter plot for my study hours project) - Write clear explanations of what was being visualized
For the Hobbies page, it helped me: - Create a simple bar chart visualization - Organize content into logical sections



Instead of just giving code, GenAI explained: - How Quarto renders .qmd files to HTML - The difference between GitHub Pages branch sources - Best practices for data visualization principles






As someone new to Quarto and GitHub Pages, I went from zero to a functional website in hours instead of days.



When stuck on technical issues (like the GitHub Pages setup), GenAI provided immediate troubleshooting steps instead of me spending hours searching forums.



The AI suggested best practices I wouldn’t have known: - Using proper YAML formatting - Adding alt text for images - Creating responsive designs



For the homepage design, GenAI provided multiple layout options I could adapt rather than starting from a blank page.






At times, I noticed myself wanting to ask GenAI for every small decision instead of thinking through problems myself.



Some suggestions needed verification: - Generated R code sometimes had syntax errors - GitHub instructions occasionally referenced outdated interfaces - Had to cross-check with official documentation



For complex multi-file projects, GenAI sometimes lost track of the overall structure and gave contradictory advice.



While helpful for technical aspects, the content still needed my personal touch and authentic voice.







“How do I fix this specific error message?”
“What’s the best way to visualize this type of data?”
“Explain how GitHub Pages deployment works”





“Write my entire reflection for me”
“Create all my website content without my input”
“Make decisions about my personal experiences”








Research: Literature review assistance, data analysis code generation
Writing: Structuring essays, checking grammar, improving clarity
Studying: Creating study guides, explaining complex concepts





Coding Projects: Debugging assistance, learning new frameworks
Documentation: Writing technical documentation and reports
Problem Solving: Brainstorming solutions to complex problems





I developed this workflow: 1. Try myself first: Attempt to solve the problem 2. Get stuck: Identify exactly where I’m stuck 3. Ask specific questions: Instead of “build my website”, ask “how do I connect Quarto to GitHub Pages?” 4. Understand, don’t just copy: Ask for explanations of suggested solutions 5. Apply and adapt: Modify suggestions to fit my specific needs





The most valuable insight I gained is that GenAI works best as an assistant rather than a replacement for learning. When I used it to explain concepts and debug specific issues, I actually learned more than if I had just copied working code.



I made sure to: - Use GenAI for learning and assistance, not to complete work for me - Add my personal experiences and voice to all content - Understand and be able to explain all code I used - Acknowledge GenAI’s role in my learning process



While GenAI accelerated this project, I made conscious effort to: - Learn the underlying principles (how Quarto works, why certain visualizations are effective) - Develop my own problem-solving skills alongside using AI - Maintain authenticity in my personal reflections and experiences








Aspect
My Usage Level
Reflection




Technical Setup
High
Essential for learning new tools


Content Creation
Moderate
Used for structure, not content


Debugging
High
Saved significant time


Learning
High
Excellent for explanations


Creativity
Low
Maintained my personal voice







GenAI democratizes technical skills - Makes web development accessible to non-coders
The human-AI partnership is powerful - My domain knowledge + AI’s technical knowledge
Critical thinking remains essential - Must verify and understand AI suggestions
Ethical use requires transparency - Acknowledging assistance while maintaining integrity


“Technology is best when it brings people together.” - Matt Mullenweg
GenAI, when used thoughtfully, can be that bridge between technical complexity and human creativity.
